passages.text: The Results Dissector (Jason Steed)

"We are such stuff as dreams are made on, and our little life is rounded with a sleep." (The Tempest, Act IV, Scene 1). The past season echoed Prospero's words: a rally built less on earnings substance than on sentiment, flows, and a sense of optimism. Healthcare and Tech faltered, REITs and Discretionary led the charge, and the market overall gained. Earnings downgrades persisted through the month, with only \(17\%\) of companies seeing upgrades post results.
NextDC (Bob Chen) (NXT AU, OW)

NXT's FY25 result highlighted several positive developments, including the accelerated billing of the forward order book driven by AI, a JV partnership for NXT's first Japan data center, and progress towards setting up a JV structure for NXT's hyperscale S4 and S7 facilities. The FY25 result and guidance for FY26 were broadly in- line with JPME and consensus, whilst the pull forward of billing capacity drives upgrades to FY27 EBITDA. The company was also upbeat on the prospects of another record year of contract wins in FY26, which could drive billing from FY27/FY28+. NXT has appointed advisors to find a capital partner to build out S4 and S7, and in our view this materially de- risks a near- term capital raise as we see the business as being well funded for sites that are currently under construction. Near term, we see the pending approval of the S5 facility as a potential catalyst for the stock, with right sounding confident on the call.
Harvey Norman (Ryan Raymond) (HVN AU, OW, PT A\$6.50)
FY25 Result, first Take - Leverage to an improving cycle

Key insights: Harvey Norman's FY25 result was broadly in- line with expectations for Australian Franchisees (\$344m PBT +2% vs. \$339th JPME) and the group (\$590m Underlying PBT vs. \$588m JPME). The focus is on the LFL sales momentum through 2H25 and into the July trading update in Australia (+5.3% in 1H25 to +6.6% in 2H25 and +6.4% in July) and NZ (-2.5% in 1H25 to +4.7% in 2H25 and +7.2% in July). Off a low base in recent years, Harvey Norman is finally seeing leverage to an improving cycle. The fixed- cost nature of the franchised model in Australia leads to high levels of operating leverage at earnings, which presents upside to consensus in FY26 given improving sales growth.
Austal Limited (Don Carducci) (ASB AU, N, PT A\$7.10)
Rising Tides - FY25 result

ASB delivered \(\sim \Delta\) 113m of EBIT in FY25, significantly ahead of consensus expectations \((+19\%)\) . After backing out the \(\Delta\) 6.3m uplift from the accounting treatment of the MMF3 facility, the \(+13\%\) earnings beat was driven by a strong Australasian print, more than offsetting earnings declines in US Shipbuilding. Beyond the growing order book, we expect near- term earnings to remain supported by the recognition of MMF3 proceeds. While tailwinds are clearly evident, we retain our Neutral rating on valuation grounds but also note elevated operational risk as ASB undertakes multiple new shipbuilding programs. PT A\(7.10.

RBA system credit growth (ex FIs) was very strong at \(8.9\%\) mom annualised in July, up from \(6.8\%\) in June. Housing credit growth decelerated slightly to \(6.1\%\) but remains healthy (investor lending outperforming owner- occupier), while non- financial business rebounded to \(16.9\%\) (from \(6.3\%\) in June). CBA was the only major bank to grow mortgages above ADI system levels, with NAB slightly behind and ANZ/WBC lagging. The majors on average lost mortgage share again this month, reflecting strong growth from MQG/ING. In business lending, WBC grew above system levels (ex- FI) with ANZ significantly lagging the majors this month. CBA and NAB both grew business ex- FI slightly below ADI system levels but still posted strong growth. Of the regional banks, BEN and BOQ both saw declines in mortgages, as has been flagged by management. However, we note BOQ's run- off accelerated meaningfully from last month and may have contributed to the more cautious outlook commentary from yesterday's trading update.
Sustainability Wire (Jean- Xavier Hecker/Noemie de la Gorce, CFA/Hugo Dubourg)
Mainstreaming Sustainability: News & Content Highlights from Equity Research
Top of the Agenda...

Our 2025 EMEA Sustainable Investing 'Back to School' is out, highlighting the rise of a new generation of Article 8 funds, the widening transatlantic divide, and the emergence of 'sovereignty' as the new thematic darling. Link
Daily Economic Briefing (Maia G Crook)

The second release of 2Q25 GDP delivered an upward revision to a \(3.3\%\) a gain. The material upward revision to domestic final sales growth (from \(1.1\%\) to \(1.6\%\) ) was concentrated in nonresidential business investment, where every category was revised up. The stwing in equipment spending gains from 1Q25 has moderated, with gains now at a \(7.4\%\) . Intellectual property product spending was notably weak last year, rising just \(2.7\%\) , but with today's upward revision it is now up a \(9.3\%\) a in 1H25. This rebound can principally be attributed to a \(22\%\) a rise in software spending in 1H25, which likely in part reflects earnings from selling AI software services.
Harvey Norman (Bryan Raymond) (HVN AU, OW)
FY25 Result First Take - Leverage to an improving cycle
PEXA (Tharan Jeyathasan) (PXA AU, OW)
FY25 Conference Call Feedback
Stockland (Richard Jones, CFA) (SGP AU, UW)
Feedback from post- results management meeting
APRA Jul- 25 Banking Stats (Andrew Triggs)
Business credit growth rebounds strongly in July; accelerating BOQ mortgage book run- off a concern
Australia Catalyst Calendar (Jason Steed)
1 September to 12 September 2025
The Results Dissector (Jason Steed)
Rising Through the Storm
Australia and New Zealand (Ben K Jarman)
Australian credit: Back to business (Tom Ryan)
Current FYNext FYCompanyIncreasesAustal Limited+19.8%+6.4%DecreasesFlight Centre Travel Group Ltd-6.4%-6.7%NextDC-3.7%-57.7%RevisionsBoss Energy-7.3%+0.1%PEXA+6.5%-106.3%
CompanyCommentAustal LimitedFY25 Result and earning changesBoss EnergyFY25 resultFlight Centre Travel Group LtdFY25 ResultNextDCFY25 ResultWaypoint REITFY25 Result
Source: J.P. Morgan estimates.

- "We are such stuff as dreams are made on, and our little life is rounded with a sleep." (The Tempest, Act IV, Scene 1). The past season echoed Prospero's words: a rally built less on earnings substance than on sentiment, flows, and a sense of optimism. Healthcare and Tech faltered, REITs and Discretionary led the charge, and the market overall gained. Earnings downgrades persisted through the month, with only \(17\%\) of companies seeing upgrades post results.- Gale force volatility – Over \(30\%\) of the ASX 50 moved by more than \(+/- 3z\) on result day. A number of 'blue chips' suffered record or near-record on-day declines – CSL, JHX and WOW in particular. Dramatic moves to the upside were also a regular feature of the season, with BXB, COL and QAN all gaining \(9\% +\) on-day. As we anticipated in our result season preview (link), Aug-25 set another record for volatility (see Figure 3), with nearly a third of the index moving by more than \(3z\) .- Earnings caught in the downdraft – EPS forecasts were cut across all but one sector (REITs) on a rolling post-result basis. With share prices on the rise, this translated to a \(0.54x\) P/E multiple expansion through August. The chart to the right highlights the largest P/E moves through the month. While we aren't singularly bearish – noting our REIT, Discretionary, Materials OWs – there is clear valuation stretch apparent in several segments of the market. Banks carry much of the downside embedded in our weighted index target; our team's average price target implies \(15\%\) downside across the majors.- A foul wind blows from the west – A troubling feature of this season was the trials and tribulations encountered by a range of companies with offshore operations. The malaise particularly afflicted those with US exposures, including AMC, CSL, JHX, REH and RWC. Even those doing well in the US market, notably BXB, pointed to soft and challenging macro conditions.- Beats and misses: an even balance – Our team's forecast for the beat/miss ratio (note) was again close to the mark. Their prediction was for an elevated proportion of in-line results, which proved to be the case. Misses outnumbered the beats and downside reaction to falling short (-6.2%, rel) was more than double the upside reaction to beats (+2.9% rel).

NXT's FY25 result highlighted several positive developments, including the accelerated billing of the forward order book driven by AI, a JV partnership for NXT's first Japan data center, and progress towards setting up a JV structure for NXT's hyperscale S4 and S7 facilities. The FY25 result and guidance for FY26 were broadly in- line with JPME and consensus, whilst the pull forward of billing capacity drives upgrades to FY27 EBITDA. The company was also upbeat on the prospects of another record year of contract wins in FY26, which could drive billing from FY27/FY28+. NXT has appointed advisors to find a capital partner to build out S4 and S7, and in our view this materially de- risks a near- term capital raise as we see the business as being well funded for sites that are currently under construction. Near term, we see the pending approval of the S5 facility as a potential catalyst for the stock, with mgmt sounding confident on the call.

- In-line result and guide, but accelerated billing drives FY27 upgrades. NXT reported an in-line FY25 result and provided FY26 guidance that was also broadly in-line with JPME and consensus. The company highlighted that its large forward order book (134MW) was now expected to bill earlier than previously expected, as these relate to AI deployments that convert much more quickly than traditional cloud workloads. This drives our FY27E EBITDA upgrade of +21% to ~ \(\) 353m\$

- JV structures reduce capital raise risk. NXT announced that they have appointed advisors to establish a JV for the development of the S4 and S7 data centres in Western Sydney. These two facilities are expected to deliver 850MW+ of capacity to hyperscale clients, and NXT expects \(\sim\) 15bn of total funding required over 10+ years. NXT will hold a minority stake in the JV, whilst being responsible for the management and operations of the vehicle. This will unlock access to lower cost of capital and allow higher gearing, whilst NXT still retains an economic exposure. NXT is targeting initial financial close for the JV within the next 12-18 months.

- Robust balance sheet to support near-term capex needs. NXT upsized its debt facilities to \(\) 6.4b\(earlier in the month, and currently has\) \ \(5.5bn\) of liquidity available to deploy for near-term capex needs. The company's FY26 guidance for \(\) 1.8bn-\$ 2bn of capex sits comfortably under this limit. In our view, the likely scenario where NXT may need to tap equity
markets again would be if there is an opportunity to accelerate development of a new facility (e.g. post S5 approval).

- Maintain Overweight, PT increases to \(\) 19.50/\mathrm{sh}\(. Our PT is driven by our Dec-26 DCF-based valuation. NXT's forward order book underwrites growth into the next few years, and we expect further contract wins to help extend that runway. The company is also well placed to continue benefitting from the secular growth in data centre infrastructure. We've revised our earnings to reflect the new billing ramp, and our EBITDA over FY26E/FY27E increases by \(+1\% / + 21\%\) .
Harvey Norman (Bryan Raymond) (HVN AU, OW, PT A\$6.50)

Key insights: Harvey Norman's FY25 result was broadly in- line with expectations for Australian Franchisees ( \(344m PBT + 2\%\) vs. \(\) 339m JPME) and the group ( \(\) 590m Underlying PBT vs. \(\) 588m JPME). The focus is on the LFL sales momentum through 2H25 and into the July trading update in Australia (+5.3% in 1H25 to +6.6% in 2H25 and +6.4% in July) and NZ (-2.5% in 1H25 to +4.7% in 2H25 and +7.2% in July). Off a low base in recent years, Harvey Norman is finally seeing leverage to an improving cycle. The fixed- cost nature of the franchised model in Australia leads to high levels of operating leverage at earnings, which presents upside to consensus in FY26 given improving sales growth.

- Key positives: 1) Australian Franchisee sales growth accelerating through FY25. Harvey Norman has seen Australian LFL sales momentum accelerate from +5.3% in 1H25 to +6.6% in 2H25 and +6.4% in July. This compares to our forecasts of 4.5% in 2H25 and 4.0% in 1H26. The fixed-cost nature of the franchised model in Australia leads to high levels of operating leverage to sales at PBT. We forecast FY26 PBT growth of 14.4% from sales growth of 4.5%. 2) NZ has turned the corner. NZ sales have picked up markedly in response to large RBNZ rate cuts, from -2.5% in 1H25 to +4.7% in 2H25 and +7.2% in July. This is the clearest sign yet through reporting season that NZ is seeing better trading conditions. 3) Inventory levels moderating. Receivables from franchisees moderated YoY, from \(\) 812m\(13.4% of network sales) to\) \ \(785m\) (12.2% of network sales), indicating there is a healthy franchisee inventory position as at 30 June, supporting margins in 1H26.

- Key negative: UK establishment losses widen. UK losses expanded from -\(10.1m in 1H25 to -\)12.3m in 2H25 as it remains sub-scale with just 1 store currently in the Midlands. The second store is scheduled to open in CY26.

- Outlook and guidance: No guidance provided, but a strong July trading update with group LFL sales growth of +8.7%, underpinned by Australia (+6.4%). Store network update for FY26: 1 new store in Australia, 1 in the UK in CY26, 4 in Malaysia and 1 store opened on 8 August in Singapore.
- Likely change to consensus: Mid to high single digit consensus upgrades to FY26, driven by strong sales momentum in Australia and NZ.
Austal Limited (Don Carducci) (ASB AU, N, PT A\$7.10)

ASB delivered \(\sim \mathbb{A}113m\) of EBIT in FY25, significantly ahead of consensus expectations \((+19\%)\) . After backing out the A\$6.3m uplift from the accounting treatment of the MMF3 facility, the \(+13\%\) earnings beat was driven by a strong Australasian print, more than offsetting earnings declines in US Shipbuilding. Beyond the growing order book, we expect near- term earnings to remain supported by the recognition of MMF3 proceeds. While tailwinds are clearly evident, we retain our Neutral rating on valuation grounds but also note elevated operational risk as ASB undertakes multiple new shipbuilding programs. PT A\$7.10.

- MMF3 contract boosts earnings. ASB confirmed accounting treatment of the US\$450m submarine manufacturing contract; US\$350m ( \(\sim \mathbb{A}526m\) ) was invoiced and paid in FY25. Of the US\$350m, ASB has estimated a revenue/earnings uplift of A\$6.2m in FY25, A\$23.3m in FY26 and \(\sim \mathbb{A}559m\) per annum over the remaining 8.5 years as performance obligations are met. Worth noting, a release of \(\sim \mathbb{A}59m\) suggests a \(40\%\) uplift to cons FY27 EBIT estimates (A\$148m). ASB has paid tax of \(\sim \mathbb{U}580m\) on the US\$350m invoiced with a direct drop down to the bottom line. This drives earnings upgrades of FY26/27 EBIT \(+10\% / + 14\%\) ; however, these provisions unwind and are non-cash. The remaining US\$100m is expected to be booked towards the end of construction.

- Return to profitability. ASB reported FY25 EBIT of A\$113m, following the pre-guide of \(\sim \mathbb{A}100m\) . Backing out \(\sim \mathbb{S}6m\) of MMF3 proceeds recognised in FY25, ASB's underlying EBIT would have been \$107m. The key driver of the result was the turnaround in Australasia Ship Building with a \$46m earnings swing (FY25 EBIT of \$24m vs FY24 EBIT of - \$22m) largely driven by improved utilisation in the Philippines/Vietnam yoy and continued LCM activity. US Shipbuilding EBIT reduced - 15% vs pcp with margins falling \(\sim 100\) bps vs pcp due to completion of higher-margin LCS and EPF contracts and a
continued drag from onerous contracts (AFDM and T- ATS). The T- ATS REA is expected to be finalised in 1H26.

- Cash flow and balance sheet. ASB delivered a strong cash performance, ending the year in a net cash position of \(\) 453m\(and NOCF of\) \ \(406m\) , with a significant uptick due to milestone receipts MMF3 and capital proceeds. Excluding the milestone payments, a \(-\) 200m inventory build (due to complications with the T-ATS program) was a drag on working capital but partly offset by a shortening of the invoice cycle in Australasia.

- Earnings & Valuation: At Jun-25, the company had an order book (incl. options) of \(\sim\) \ \(13.1bn, diversified across multiple programs. The SSA signing is expected to generate significant order book growth in 1H26 with the 'LCM' program alone expected to be\) \ \(1.0 - 1.3bn\) . ASB highlighted the possibility of 'LCM' and 'LCH' programs to contribute \(\sim\) \ \(5bn to the order book by CY25 end. Our FY26/27 earnings increase (EBIT +10%/+14%) along with our comp-co multiples. Acknowledging the significant industry tailwinds we remain Neutral given our upgraded PT (\) \ \(7.10\) remains below the share price.

RBA system credit growth (ex FIs) was very strong at \(8.9\%\) mom annualised in July, up from \(6.8\%\) in June. Housing credit growth decelerated slightly to \(6.1\%\) but remains healthy (investor lending outperforming owner- occupier), while non- financial business rebounded to \(16.9\%\) (from \(6.3\%\) in June). CBA was the only major bank to grow mortgages above ADI system levels, with NAB slightly behind and ANZ/WBC lagging. The majors on average lost mortgage share again this month, reflecting strong growth from MQG/ING. In business lending, WBC grew above system levels (ex- FI) with ANZ significantly lagging the majors this month. CBA and NAB both grew business ex- FI slightly below ADI system levels but still posted strong growth. Of the regional banks, BEN and BOQ both saw declines in mortgages, as has been flagged by management. However, we note BOQ's run- off accelerated meaningfully from last month and may have contributed to the more cautious outlook commentary from yesterday's trading update.

- Mortgage growth: RBA system mortgage growth decelerated to \(6.1\%\) (while non-seasonally adjusted APRA was \(4.2\%\) ). On average, the majors lost share (2.9% growth) dragged down by WBC (1.0%) and ANZ (2.1%). WBC continues to face headwinds from the roll-off of the RAMS portfolio and is prioritising growth in business lending. Comparatively, ANZ saw its weakest month of loan growth since May-22. CBA (4.4%) grew just above system, while NAB grew slightly behind at \(3.7\%\) . RBA rate cuts should increase borrowing capacity and provide modest support to system volume growth.

- Business lending growth (ex-FI): RBA system business growth ex select FIs was \(16.9\%\) annualised, up on a softer June result (6.3%), noting that the series is more volatile than housing. APRA and individual bank data was driven by seasonality after the financial year end, with WBC growing the fastest (14.4%, ahead of APRA system \(11.9\%\) ). CBA and NAB also grew strongly at \(8.9\%\) and \(7.5\%\) respectively. ANZ (4.1%) continued to meaningfully lag the majors. Lending to FIs was a tailwind for all majors except ANZ. Business credit growth continues to run above JPME.

- Non-majors: MQG saw another strong month in July for mortgages (26.7%) with business ex-FI also up (10.8%) after a weak June. MQG now has \(6.3\%\) market share in mortgages; our view of its potential natural level is \(\sim 10\%\) . BEN's mortgage book declined further as repricing efforts flagged by management took time to flow through. BEN is aiming to return to system levels by end-FY26. BEN's business growth also declined, likely driven by seasonality in agriculture. BOQ's mortgage decline continued at an accelerated pace (-19.7%) with business ex-FI also down. JDO's total loan growth (8.0%) stepped down from record levels last month but remained above system.

- Deposits: Deposit growth was strong at \(14.3\%\) annualised, driven by very healthy household trends (26.1%) which was ahead of business (2.4%). We are reminded there is seasonality in deposit levels after the June financial year-end.
